p: The color of meat strongly affects consumer acceptability and influences consumer purchase decisions [ 50]. As reviewed by Neethling et al. [ 51], consumers perceive bright, cherry-red meat as fresher and more wholesome than discolored and/or dark meat, which is usually associated with the DFD defect. However, as pointed out by Ramanzin et al. [ 52], a more intense or darker red color of venison seems to be acceptable to consumers because it is considered a typical feature of this type of meat. The typical darker and red-brown color of venison can be attributed to the higher content of myoglobin compared with meat of other domestic livestock species [ 53]. According to Volpelli et al. [ 10], this darker color is characterized by L* value < 40, high a* values and lower b* values.
